questions.question_text:
You work as a Systems Administrator for your company. The company has several departments.
The company has a subscription to Microsoft 365. All users in your company have a Microsoft 365 E5 license.
You have configured a Team for each of the departments.
You need to ensure that you are notified if a user creates a new Team by using the Create a Team option in the Microsoft Teams client.
Which of the following actions should you perform?

choices.B: Right click on the Teams icon and select Get Logs.
choices.C: Use Windows Event Viewer and browse to the Application Log.
choices.A: Press the following key combination: Ctrl+Alt+Shift+1.
choices.D: Run a Usage report in the Teams admin center.

questions.question_text:
You work as a Systems Administrator for your company. The company has a subscription to Microsoft 365.
All users in your company have a Microsoft 365 E5 license.
A user named User1 has the Microsoft Teams desktop client on his Windows 10 client computer.
User1 reports several problems when using Microsoft Teams.
You need to view the debug logs on User1's computer.
Which of the following actions should you perform to generate the debug logs?

discussion.content:
This question could be confusing considering that we have two options to get client logs.
One is clicking the MS Teams icon in the system tray and select "Get logs" (this works for MacOS and Windows).
In another hand we have the option to press (in windows) CTRL + Alt + Shift + 1. (In MacOS) Option + Command + Shift + 1.

In the question is not specifiying the Teams in the icon system try and either the operative system. In my opinion both answer A and B should be correct. I have to choose one, I will select the A, because the exam is for an MS Teams admin role which means you know more details to get the information.

comments.content: Desktop and media logs are required only by MS support. These 2 requires getting logs through system tray MS Teams icon. Debug is gotten through the keyboard combinations
Yes, there are two ways. But the specifically asked to view "debug logs". So the keyboards shortcut is most appropriate answer.

discussion.content: answer is correct. :https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/log-files
A and B seem to do the exact same thing. Exact same log files are generated.

A and B literally do they exact same thing. I just tested this, and both methods download a folder named MSTeams Diagnostics Log with the date and time. The folder contains three folders named Desktop, Meeting, Web. They all contain the exact same files.. We all can test this within 2 minutes ourselves if you have Teams installed.

The correct answer should be...
Press the following key combination: Ctrl+Alt+Shift+1 whilst in the TEAMS App
Answer is correct. Mr Nel and Mr Moseki, please note.
Answer is A

Selected Answer: A
Now this one got me, but as the wording "Get Logs" is wrong here when using right click on the Teams tray icon, answer "A" seems to be the best choice.

Selected Answer: A
Ctrl+Alt+Shift+1.

Selected Answer: A
This is the correct answer. The keyboard shortcut works for me after testing.

Selected Answer: A
The Answer is A because the wording in Answer B should be clicking the MS Teams icon in the system tray and select "Collect Support files"
Answer is correct...

As per Microsoft "To collect logs for Browser and Windows: Keyboard shortcut: Ctrl + Alt + Shift + 1". It doesn't work for me. Rather clicking on Teams icon and click on "Get Logs" works.
The files will be available in %userprofile%\Downloads

choices.B: Assign the Security Administrator role to the manager.
choices.C: Assign the Reports Reader role to the manager.
choices.D: Assign the Compliance Manager role to the manager.
choices.A: Assign the Teams Communications Administrator role to the manager.

discussion.content: C is correct!

Selected Answer: C
The correct answer is C. With reports reader access they can access the information they need and nothing more, which follows the security rule of least priviledge.

Selected Answer: C
I think this is referring to the Usage reports in the O365 admin center, not the ones in Teams admin.

Selected Answer: C
There’s something missing here.
According to MS “ You must be either a global admin, ***global reader and reports reader***, or Teams service admin to view the reports in Teams admin center”
There is an “and” requiring both roles, and yet “C” is the closest answer …..

View the usage report:
You must be either a global admin, global reader and reports reader, or Teams service admin to view the reports in Teams admin center

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/teams-analytics-and-reports/teams-usage-report

What kind or usage report do they mean? As an Global Admin you can assign the role "Global Reader" to a user. This user does not have acces to the Usage Report in the Teams Admin Center (TAC), only to the dashboard for Teams, available in M365 Admin Center Usage / Microsoft Teams / Teams usage. However, this report only information at a higher level than the Report in Teams admin Center.
From link below: "How to access the reports: Global Reader (only tenant-level aggregate and no per-user or team data)"
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/teams-analytics-and-reports/teams-reporting-reference
However, only C fits best but this is not a usage report as shown in TAC.

Selected Answer: C
They only need to be able to read the reports and that ends up being the least usage rights of them all. Even though A would also be a correct method, A has more privileges than C.

Selected Answer: C
Just verified this in my test tenant. After assigning the manager the report reader role he will be able to see Teams usage report in the 365 admin center.

Answer is C.

comments.content: C is correct because of "least privilege". As Reports Reader role will achieve the requirements, but A will achieve the requirements and give more privileges to manager and actually no need, he is not an administrator to give him administrator role. So, the Reports Reader role is enough.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
That's a tricky one, but answer "A" seems to be more correct. The buzzwords "least privilege" and "Teams Usage Reports" (which can only be found in Teams Admin Center) are pointing to the "Teams Communications Administrator" role.

Answer "C" says Reports Reader, that is not valid here in my opinion.

Source:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-US/microsoftteams/using-admin-roles

comments.content: Tricky though, because all this link gives you is AzureAD cmdlets to connect to the Azure Admin Center. Yes, you can do both, but the above link doesn't specifically say you can use the AAD GUI.

discussion.content:
Answer is correct, tested on my own enviroment, however consider the following: 
With the proper admin roles you can either restore a deleted group from Azure Active Directory Center or Microsoft 365 Admin Center within the first 30 days after deletion (soft deletion time), consider this if you have either one of the two options, if you have both, I would select Microsoft 365 Admin Center, considering the least privilege, it is easier to have access to 365 admin center than AAD. 
Apparently the owner of the group is also able to restore this deleted group within the first 30 days after deletion in the office 365. I am assuming this is in Outlook or SharePoint. I was not able to test this part.

Selected Answer: C
This is a question that speaks to an OLDER VERSION of Teams. You can now access deleted teams from within the Teams Admin Center > Manage teams > Actions (upper right corner) > View deleted teams. HOWEVER, for the test... the answer is still C.

Microsoft Teams Admin Center is more appropriate here, as it is meant for managing teams rather than groups, which is been managed through AAD

a. Teams admin center can do that

Selected Answer: A
To restore a deleted team in Microsoft Teams, you should use:

A. The Microsoft Teams admin center

The Microsoft Teams admin center allows you to manage and restore deleted teams, ensuring that your users can continue their collaboration without interruption.

Selected Answer: A
The Microsoft Teams admin center allows you to manage and restore deleted teams.

Selected Answer: A
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/manage-teams-in-modern-portal

Restore deleted teams
To restore a deleted team in the Teams admin center, do the following:
Go to the Teams Admin center > Teams > Manage teams.
Expand Actions menu on the top right corner, click View deleted teams.
Select the team that you want to restore from the list, and then click Restore. You can also select multiple teams and restore them.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/manage-teams-in-modern-portal

If you're a groups administrator, you can restore a deleted group in the Microsoft 365 admin center:

Go to the Microsoft 365 admin center.
Expand Groups, and then select Deleted groups.
Select the group that you want to restore, and then select Restore group.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/create-groups/restore-deleted-group?view=o365-worldwide&tabs=admin-center

But to restore a deleted team in Microsoft Teams, the correct tool to use is the Microsoft Teams admin center. The Azure Active Directory admin center (option C) is primarily used for managing users and groups, not for restoring deleted Teams.

If you need help navigating the Microsoft Teams admin center to restore the team, feel free to ask!

Selected Answer: A
https://admin.teams.microsoft.com/teams/manage/deleted-teams
Here you can restore the deleted team.

discussion.content: Option A, The Microsoft Teams admin center, is correct because as a Systems Administrator, you can use the Microsoft Teams admin center to restore a deleted team in Microsoft 365. In the Microsoft Teams admin center, you can access the Teams feature, and view a list of all the teams in your organization. From this list, you can select the deleted team, and then restore it. This allows you to recover the deleted team and its associated data, such as channels, conversations, files, and members. The Microsoft Teams admin center provides a centralized location for managing and administering Microsoft Teams, making it the ideal tool for restoring deleted teams in Microsoft 365.

Selected Answer: C

questions.question_text:
You work as a Systems Administrator for your company. The company has a subscription to Microsoft 365. All users in your company have a Microsoft 365 E5 license.
All users in the company use Microsoft Teams for collaboration.
Users report that a team has been deleted in Microsoft Teams. The team was available yesterday.
You need to restore the deleted team.
Which tool should you use?

choices.C: The Azure Active Directory admin center

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I think B - Guest Access in Users is wrong. That only allows guest access and a few simple settings like being able to share your screen, messaging, etc. Nothing about Meetings.

The requirement for guests was specially about meetings:
Contoso identifies the following meeting and live event requirements:
Requirement1: Guest users must be able to join live events.
Requirement2: Guest users must always wait in a meeting lobby.
Requirement3: Contoso users must always bypass the meeting lobby when they join meetings by using the Microsoft Teams client.

C - The Global Meeting Policy makes way more sense in this scenario (at least for the 2nd and 3rd requirements)
TAC > Meetings > Meeting Policies > Participants & Guest has those settings. Specifically Automatically admit people - people in my organization.

The 1st requirement is specifically about live events (Requirement1: Guest users must be able to join live events), but there is no live event option here.

comments.content:
You are incorrect, answer is B.

The question is asking to meet the Technical Requirement, which is "Guest users must be prevented from making private calls". 

The requirements you mentioned below are "meeting and live event requirements", NOT "Technical Requirement"!
Requirement1: Guest users must be able to join live events.
Requirement2: Guest users must always wait in a meeting lobby.
yes well spotted... you need to meet the TECHNICAL REQUIREMENTS so B

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The question is asking to meet the Technical Requirement, which is "Guest users must be prevented from making private calls".

Selected Answer: B
The question is about Technical requirements, not Device requirement

Selected Answer: B
The giving answer is correct. The guest user must already wait before he can join the live event by defualt!

Selected Answer: B
Second option in Guest access under users us ability for a guest to make a call

Selected Answer: B
Technical Requirements - Guest users must be prevented from making private calls.

Selected Answer: B
Answer is correct. Guest access under Users. In the policy, Under Calling, there is a Make private calls option – Turn this setting On to allow guests to make peer-to-peer calls.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/set-up-guests

Selected Answer: B
It would be B. Tech Requirement is: Guest users must be prevented from making private calls which is under TAC | Users | Guest access, Manage calling setting for Guests...
Answer is correct
